site.name: McGheeLab
site.mission: We build simple, open, and robust bioengineering tools—microfluidics, bioprinting, and biomechanics—to make high‑impact science accessible.

sections.title: Accessible Tools. Reproducible Science.
sections.body: Our lab designs straightforward, low‑cost systems that let more people run high‑quality experiments. We publish open protocols and build hardware that can be fabricated with basic equipment.

sections.title: From Forces to Function
sections.body: We measure and modulate mechanical cues—from single‑cell traction to tissue‑scale stresses—to understand how forces drive biology.

topics.title: Microfluidics
topics.summary: Simple, modular chips for flow control, droplet generation, and single‑cell handling. We emphasize 3D‑printed and tape‑bonded devices that cut fabrication time from days to hours.

topics.title: 3D Bioprinting
topics.summary: Hydrogel bioinks with tunable rheology for high‑viability prints. Our goal is practical tissue models, not just pretty lattices.

topics.title: Traction Force Microscopy
topics.summary: End‑to‑end TFM: gel prep, bead embedding, image registration, and force inversion with uncertainty quantification.
topics.imageAlt: Cell traction vectors on a gel

topics.title: Bead‑Based ELISA
topics.summary: Microsphere assays for multiplexed detection with minimal sample volume—great for microfluidic outlets and time‑courses.

topics.title: Biomechanics
topics.summary: From single‑cell to tissue mechanics: viscoelastic measurements, strain fields, and constitutive modeling.

projects.title: Open Microfluidic Pump
projects.summary: A <$100 peristaltic pump with closed‑loop flow sensing and printable parts.

projects.title: Cartilage Bioink
projects.summary: Shear‑thinning, fast‑recovering hydrogel for high cell viability and shape retention.

projects.title: TFM Toolkit
projects.summary: A Python toolbox for bead tracking, drift correction, and force inversion with examples.
